explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_solids.rationale: Non-combustible (BGIA, GESTIS-database on hazardous substancess, Accessed in 2006)

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Non-combustible (BGIA, GESTIS-database on hazardous substancess, Accessed in 2006)

self_heating_substances.rationale: Non-combustible (GESTIS-database on hazardous substances, accessed in 2006)

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Stable to water (the water solubility is obtained)

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Category 5 based on SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LD50; VALUE: 3031mg/kg; REFERENCE SOURCE: HSDB (2003) RTECS (2004)

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Since there is the description that this product stimulates human skin (HSDB, 2003;SITTIG, 2002), it was thought that it had mild stimulant and it was set to category 3.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: With this product, from the description (HSDB, 2003;SITTIG, 2002) that the human eye is stimulated, and by ACGIH-TLV (2005), there was eye irritation in fluoride. So it is set as Category 2A-2B. In addition, from these information, detailed categorization is difficult.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitization: Classification not possible; Skin sensitization: Classification not possible

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: No data. In addition, in ATSDR (draft, 2005), there is the description that lead induces chromosome aberration to humans, and the inorganic lead compound is classified into the germ cell mutagenicities 3A (equivalent to GHS Category 1B-2) according to MAK/BAT (2005).

carcinogenicity.hazard_statement: May cause cancer (state route of exposure if it is conclusively proven that no other routes of exposure cause the hazard)
carcinogenicity.rationale: There is no data of this product. But as a lead compound, it is equivalent to Category1B (inorganic lead compounds, Group 2A ) in IARC87 (2004), equivalent to Category1B-2 (Reasonably anticipated to be human carcinogens) in NTPRoC (11th, 2005), and equivalent to Category 2 (respectively B-2, A3, 2B) in IRIS (1993), ACGIH-TLV (2005), and Occupational Health Society advice (2005).Therefore, it was set as Category 1B according to Group 2A of IARC87 (2004).

toxic_to_reproduction.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the undorn child
toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based on the result that increase in testicular toxicity and fetus lethality were observed by administering this substance to male rats (RTECS, 2004), and the statement in ACGIH-TLV (2004) and ATSDR (draft, 2005) of Priority 1 document, etc. that lead (inorganic lead compounds) indicates reproductive toxicity in humans. So it was set as Category 1A.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system, blood system, kidneys); Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs (central nervous system, blood system, kidneys); May cause respiratory irritation or may cause drowsiness and dizziness (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Since there is description in CERI Hazard Data2001-9 (2001) of Priority 1 document "in acute effects and chronic effects, almost the same symptoms are observed" as human impact of inorganic lead compound, and in ACGIH-TLV (2005), inorganic lead compounds effect on the central nervous systems, blood, and kidney, so it was considered as Category 1 (a central nervous system, blood, kidney). Moreover, in ACGIH-TLV (2005), it is supposed that fluoride has respiratory irritant. Since there was the same description also in SITTIG (2002) and HSFS (1999), it was considered as Category 3 (respiratory irritant).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (bone, central nervous system, blood, kidneys)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (bone, central nervous system, blood, kidneys) through prolonged or repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Although there is no data of this product, since fluoride had the influence on a bone (fluorosis), and since inorganic lead compounds had the effects on central nervous systems, blood, and renal (ACGIH-TLV (2005) of Priority 1 document), it was classified into Category 1 (a bone, a central nervous system, blood, kidney).
